metadata.title: The sequence of human ACE2 is suboptimal for binding the S spike protein of SARS coronavirus 2

abstract.text: The rapid and escalating spread of SARS coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) 6 poses an immediate public health emergency. The viral spike protein S binds ACE2 7 on host cells to initiate molecular events that release the viral genome 8
intracellularly. Soluble ACE2 inhibits entry of both SARS and SARS-2 coronaviruses 9 by acting as a decoy for S binding sites, and is a candidate for therapeutic, 10
prophylactic and diagnostic development. Using deep mutagenesis, variants of ACE2 11
are identified with increased binding to the receptor binding domain of S. Mutations 12 are found across the interface, in the N90-glycosylation motif, and at buried sites 13
where they are predicted to enhance local folding and presentation of the interaction 14 epitope. When single substitutions are combined, large increases in binding can be 15
achieved. The mutational landscape offers a blueprint for engineering high affinity 16 proteins and peptides that block receptor binding sites on S to meet this 17 unprecedented challenge. 18

body_text.text: In December, 2019, a novel zoonotic betacoronavirus closely related to bat coronaviruses 19 spilled over to humans, possibly at the Huanan Seafood Market in the Chinese city of 20

Wuhan (1, 2) . The virus, called SARS-CoV-2 due to its similarities with the severe acute 21 respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus responsible for a smaller outbreak nearly two 22 decades prior (3, 4), has since spread human-to-human rapidly across the world, 23

precipitating extraordinary containment measures from governments (5). These events 24 are unlike any experienced in generations. Symptoms of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-25 19) range from mild to dry cough, fever, pneumonia and death, and SARS-CoV-2 is 26 devastating among the elderly and other vulnerable groups (6, 7). 27

The S spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 binds angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) on 28 host cells (2, 8-13). S is a trimeric class I viral fusion protein that is proteolytically 29 processed into S1 and S2 subunits that remain noncovalently associated in a prefusion 30 state (8, 11, 14) . Upon engagement of ACE2 by a receptor binding domain (RBD) in S1 (15), 31 conformational rearrangements occur that cause S1 shedding, cleavage of S2 by host 32 proteases, and exposure of a fusion peptide adjacent to the S2' proteolysis site (14, (16) (17) (18) . 33 Favorable folding of S to a post-fusion conformation is coupled to host cell/virus 34 membrane fusion and cytosolic release of viral RNA. Atomic contacts with the RBD are 35 restricted to the protease domain of ACE2 (19, 20) , and soluble ACE2 (sACE2) in which the 36 transmembrane domain is removed is sufficient for binding S and neutralizing infection 37 (12, (21) (22) (23) (24) . In principle, the virus has limited potential to escape sACE2-mediated 38 neutralization without simultaneously decreasing affinity for native ACE2 receptors, 39 thereby attenuating virulence. Furthermore, fusion of sACE2 to the Fc region of human 40 immunoglobulin can provide an avidity boost while recruiting immune effector functions 41 and increasing serum stability, an especially desirable quality if intended for prophylaxis 42 (23, 25) , and sACE2 has proven safe in healthy human subjects (26) and patients with lung 43 disease (27). Recombinant sACE2 is being evaluated in a European phase II clinical trial for 44 COVID-19 managed by Apeiron Biologics, and peptide derivatives of ACE2 are also being 45 explored as cell entry inhibitors (28). 46
Since human ACE2 has not evolved to recognize SARS-CoV-2 S, it was hypothesized that 47 mutations may be found that increase affinity for therapeutic and diagnostic applications. 48

The coding sequence of full length ACE2 with an N-terminal c-myc epitope tag was 49 diversified to create a library containing all possible single amino acid substitutions at 117 50 sites spanning the entire interface with S and lining the substrate-binding cavity. S binding 51 is independent of ACE2 catalytic activity (23) typically yield no more than one coding variant per cell, providing a tight link between 60 genotype and phenotype (32, 33). Cells were then incubated with a subsaturating dilution 61 of medium containing the RBD of SARS-CoV-2 fused C-terminally to superfolder GFP 62 (sfGFP: (34)) ( Fig. 1A) . Levels of bound RBD-sfGFP correlate with surface expression levels 63 of myc-tagged ACE2 measured by dual color flow cytometry. Compared to cells expressing 64 wild type ACE2 (Fig. 1C ), many variants in the ACE2 library fail to bind RBD, while there 65 appeared to be a smaller number of ACE2 variants with higher binding signals (Fig. 1D ). 66

Cells expressing ACE2 variants with high or low binding to RBD were collected by 67 fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS), referred to as "nCoV-S-High" and "nCoV-S-Low" 68 sorted populations, respectively. During FACS, fluorescence signal for bound RBD-sfGFP 69 continuously declined, requiring the collection gates to be regularly updated to 'chase' the 70 relevant populations. This is consistent with RBD dissociating over hours during the 71 experiment. 72 were compared to the naive plasmid library to calculate the enrichment or depletion of all 99 2,340 coding mutations in the library (Fig. 2 ). This approach of tracking an in vitro 100 selection or evolution by deep sequencing is known as deep mutagenesis (35). Enrichment 101 ratios ( Fig. 3A and 3B) and residue conservation scores ( Fig. 3D and 3E) closely agree 102 between two independent sort experiments, giving confidence in the data. For the most 103 part, enrichment ratios (Fig. 3C ) and conservation scores (Fig. 3F ) in the nCoV-S-High sorts 104

are anticorrelated with the nCoV-S-Low sorts, with the exception of nonsense mutations 105 which were appropriately depleted from both gates. This indicates that most, but not all, 106 nonsynonymous mutations in ACE2 did not eliminate surface expression. The library is 107 biased towards solvent-exposed residues and has few substitutions of buried hydrophobics 108 that might have bigger effects on plasma membrane trafficking (33). 109
Mapping the experimental conservation scores from the nCoV-S-High sorts to the structure 124 of RBD-bound ACE2 (19) shows that residues buried in the interface tend to be conserved, 125

whereas residues at the interface periphery or in the substrate-binding cleft are 126 mutationally tolerant (Fig. 4A ). The region of ACE2 surrounding the C-terminal end of the 127 ACE2 α1 helix and β3-β4 strands has a weak tolerance of polar residues, while amino acids 128 at the N-terminal end of α1 and the C-terminal end of α2 prefer hydrophobics (Fig. 4B ), 129 likely in part to preserve hydrophobic packing between α1-α2. These discrete patches 130 contact the globular RBD fold and a long protruding loop of the RBD, respectively. 131

Two ACE2 residues, N90 and T92 that together form a consensus N-glycosylation motif, are 132 notable hot spots for enriched mutations ( Fig. 2 and 4A ). Indeed, all substitutions of N90 133 and T92, with the exception of T92S which maintains the N-glycan, are highly favorable for 134 RBD binding, and the N90-glycan is thus predicted to partially hinder S/ACE2 interaction. 135
This

Residues conserved for high RBD binding are orange; mutationally tolerant residues are pale 144 colors; residues that are hot spots for enriched mutations are blue; and residues maintained as 145 wild type in the ACE2 library are grey. Glycans are dark red sticks. binding, and will be useful for engineering highly specific and tight protein or peptide 160 binders of SARS-CoV-2 S. The molecular basis for how some of these mutations enhance 161 RBD binding can be rationalized from the RBD-bound cryo-EM structure (Fig. 4C ): 162 hydrophobic substitutions of ACE2-T27 increase hydrophobic packing with aromatic 163 residues of S, ACE2-D30E extends an acidic side chain to reach S-K417, and aromatic 164 substitutions of ACE2-K31 contribute to an interfacial cluster of aromatics. A search for 165 affinity-enhancing mutations in ACE2 using targeted mutagenesis recently identified D30E 166
(38), providing independent confirmation of the methods used here. 167

Attention was also drawn to mutations in the second shell and farther from the interface 168 that do not directly contact S but instead have putative structural roles. For example, 169 proline substitutions were enriched at five library positions (S19, L91, T92, T324 and 170 Q325) where they might entropically stabilize the first turns of helices. Proline was also 171 enriched at H34, where it may enforce the central bulge in α1. Multiple mutations were 172 also enriched at buried positions where they will change local packing (e.g. A25V, L29F, 173 W69V, F72Y and L351F). The selection of ACE2 variants for high binding signal therefore 174 not only reports on affinity, but also on presentation at the membrane of folded structure 175 recognized by SARS-CoV-2 S. Whether these mutations selectively stabilize a virus-176 recognized local structure in ACE2 versus the global protein fold is unclear. 177

Thirty single substitutions highly enriched in the nCoV-S-High sort were validated by 178 targeted mutagenesis (Fig. 5) . Binding of RBD-sfGFP to full length ACE2 mutants increased 179 compared to wild type, yet improvements were small and most apparent on cells 180 expressing low ACE2 levels (Fig. 5A) . Differences in ACE2 expression between the mutants 181 also correlated with total levels of bound RBD-sfGFP (Fig. 5C ). To rapidly assess mutations 182 in a format more relevant to therapeutic and diagnostic development, the soluble ACE2 183 protease domain was fused to sfGFP. Expression levels of sACE2-sfGFP were qualitatively 184 evaluated by fluorescence of the transfected cultures (Fig. 6A) , and binding of sACE2-sfGFP 185 to full length S expressed at the plasma membrane was measured by flow cytometry (Fig.  186  6B) . A single substitution (T92Q) that eliminates the N90 glycan gave a small increase in 187 binding signal (Fig. 6B) . Focusing on the most highly enriched substitutions in the selection 188 for S binding that were also spatially segregated to minimize negative epistasis (39), 189
combinations of mutations in sACE2 gave large increases in S binding (Table 1 and Fig. 6B ). 190
While this assay only provides relative differences, the combinatorial mutants
A single variant, sACE2.v2, was chosen for purification and further characterization (Fig. 7) . 218

This variant was selected because it was well expressed fused to sfGFP and maintains the 219 N90-glycan, and will therefore present a surface that more closely matches native sACE2 to 220 minimize immunogenicity. The yield of sACE2.v2 was lower than the wild type protein 221 when purified as an 8his-tagged protein (20% lower) or as an IgG1-Fc fusion (60% lower), 222 and by analytical size exclusion chromatography (SEC) a small fraction of sACE2.v2 was 223 found to aggregate after incubation at 37 °C for 40 h (Fig. 7D) . Otherwise, sACE2.v2 was 224 indistinguishable from wild type by SEC (Fig. 7C) .

(C) Analytical SEC of 8his-tagged proteins. The major peak corresponds to the expected MW 233 of a monomer. A dimer peak is also observed, although its abundance differs between 234 independent protein preparations (compare to Figure 10D ).
(D) Soluble ACE2-8h proteins were incubated at 37 °C for 40 h and analyzed by SEC.

In flow cytometry experiments using purified 8his-tagged sACE2, only sACE2.v2-8h was 237 found to bind strongly to full length S at the cell surface, suggestive that wild type sACE2 238 has a high off-rate that causes dissociation during sample washing ( Fig. 8A and 9 ). 239
Differences between wild type and the variant were less pronounced in the context of an 240
IgG1-Fc fusion ( Fig. 8A and 9) , indicating that avidity masks gains in binding of the mutant, 241
again suggestive that there are off-rate differences between wild type and variant sACE2. 242

Soluble ACE2.v2-8h outcompetes wild type sACE2-IgG1 for binding to S-expressing cells, 243 yet wild type sACE2-8h does not outcompete sACE2-IgG1 even at 10-fold higher 244 concentrations (Fig. 8B) . These results align with a study showing that while wild type 245 sACE2 is highly effective at inhibiting SARS-CoV-2 replication in cell lines and organoids, 246 extremely high concentrations are required (24). Cell experiments were supported by 247 biolayer interferometry (BLI), in which IgG1-Fc fused RBD was captured on a biosensor 248 surface and the association and dissociation kinetics of 8his-tagged sACE2 were 249
determined. The KD of wild type sACE2-8h for the RBD was 140 to 150 nM ( Fig. 8C and  250 10F), slightly higher than the KD values reported by others that range from 1 to 50 nM (8, 251

10)(40). Variant sACE2.v2 had 65-fold tighter affinity for the RBD, almost entirely due to a 252 slower off-rate (Fig. 8D) . Across all experiments, whether ACE2 is purified as a 8his-tagged 253 protein or used as a sfGFP-fusion in expression medium, and whether full-length S is 254 expressed on the plasma membrane or the isolated RBD is immobilized on a biosensor 255 surface, the characterized sACE2.v2 variant consistently shows one to two orders of 256 magnitude tighter binding. These experiments support the key discovery from deep 257 mutagenesis that mutations in human ACE2 exist that increase binding to S of SARS-CoV-2. 258
(C) BLI kinetics of wild type sACE2-8h association (t = 0 to 120 s) and dissociation (t > 120 s) 270 with immobilized RBD-IgG1. Compare to an independent protein preparation in Figure 10F .
Fluorescence of myc-S-expressing cells treated without sACE2 is black.
(C) Binding of purified wild type sACE2 (grey) or sACE2.v2 (blue) fused to 8his (solid lines) or 283 IgG1-Fc (broken lines) to cells expressing myc-S.

To address the decreased expression of sACE2.v2, it was hypothesized that the mutational 285 load is too high. Each of the four mutations in sACE2.v2 was reverted back to the wild type 286 identity (Table 1) , and binding to full length S at the cell surface was found to remain tight 287 using rapid screening of sACE2-sfGFP-containing expression medium (Fig. 10A) . 288

Expression was rescued to varying degrees (Fig. 10B) , and one of the variants (sACE2.v2.4 289 with mutations T27Y, L79T and N330Y) was purified with higher yields than wild type 290 (20% and 80% higher for 8his and IgG1-Fc tagged proteins, respectively), although some 291 protein remained aggregated after storage at 37 °C for 60 h ( Figure 10D and 10E) . A 292 second reversion variant (sACE2.v2.2 with mutations T27Y, N330Y and A386L) has a more 293 hydrophobic surface and higher propensity to partially aggregate after storage at 37 °C, 294
and therefore the partial storage instability may be intrinsically linked to increased 295 hydrophobicity of the mutated ACE2 surface. By BLI, sACE2.v2.4 displayed tight nanomolar 296

binding to the RBD (Fig. 10G) , demonstrating that high affinity can be achieved without 297 compromising protein expression and purification. Further sequence optimization focused 298 on whether to include the ACE2 neck domain for stable dimer formation is warranted. 299 Transfection Enhancers (ThermoFisher) were added 18-23 h post-transfection, and cells 340
were cultured for 4-5 days. Cells were removed by centrifugation at 800 × g for 5 minutes 341
and medium was stored at -20 °C. After thawing and immediately prior to use, remaining 342 cell debris and precipitates were removed by centrifugation at 20,000 × g for 20 minutes. 343
Plasmids for expression of sACE2-sfGFP protein were transfected in to Expi293F cells using 344

Expifectamine ( the myc-positive (Alexa 647) population, the top 67% were gated (Fig. 1B) . Of these, the 15 361 % of cells with the highest and 20% of cells with the lowest GFP fluorescence were 362 collected (Fig. 1D) in tubes coated overnight with fetal bovine serum and containing 363
Expi293 Expression Medium. Total RNA was extracted from the collected cells using a 364

GeneJET RNA purification kit (Thermo Scientific), and cDNA was reverse transcribed with 365 high fidelity Accuscript (Agilent) primed with gene-specific oligonucleotides. Diversified 366 regions of ACE2 were PCR amplified as 5 fragments. Flanking sequences on the primers 367 added adapters to the ends of the products for annealing to Illumina sequencing primers, 368 unique barcoding, and for binding the flow cell. Amplicons were sequenced on an Illumina 369
NovaSeq 6000 using a 2×250 nt paired end protocol. Data were analyzed using Enrich (42), 370

and commands are provided in the GEO deposit. Briefly, the frequencies of ACE2 variants in 371 the transcripts of the sorted populations were compared to their frequencies in the naive 372 plasmid library to calculate a log2 enrichment ratio and then normalized by the same 373 calculation for wild type. Wild type sequences were neither substantially enriched or 374 depleted, and had log2 enrichment ratios of -0.2 to +0.2. 375

Flow Cytometry Analysis of ACE2-S Binding. Expi293F cells were transfected with 376 pcDNA3-myc-ACE2, pcDNA3-myc-S or pcDNA3-S plasmids (500 ng DNA per ml of culture 377 at 2 × 10 6 / ml) using Expifectamine (ThermoFisher). Cells were analyzed by flow human IgG-APC clone HP6017 from BioLegend) for 30 minutes on ice, washed twice again, 392
and fluorescence of the total population after gating by FSC-SSC to exclude debris was 393 measured on a BD Accuri C6. Data were processed with FCS Express (De Novo Software) 394
or BD Accuri C6 Software. 395
Purification of IgG1-Fc fused proteins. Cleared expression medium was incubated with 396 KANEKA KanCapA 3G Affinity sorbent (Pall; equilibrated in PBS) for 90 minutes at 4 °C.

The resin was collected on a chromatography column, washed with 12 column volumes 398 (CV) PBS, and protein eluted with 5 CV 60 mM Acetate pH 3.7. The eluate was immediately 399 neutralized with 1 CV of 1 M Tris pH 9.0, and concentrated with a 100 kD MWCO 400

FIGREF0.text: A selection strategy for ACE2 variants with high binding to the RBD of SARS-74 CoV-2 S.

FIGREF1.text: A) Media from Expi293F cells secreting the SARS-CoV-2 RBD fused to sfGFP was collected 76 and incubated at different dilutions with Expi293F cells expressing myc-tagged ACE2. Bound

FIGREF2.text: 77RBD-sfGFP was measured by flow cytometry. The dilutions of RBD-sfGFP-containing medium 78 used for FACS selections are indicated by arrows.

FIGREF3.text: B-C) Expi293F cells were transfected with wild type ACE2 plasmid diluted with a large excess 80 of carrier DNA. It has been previously shown that under these conditions, cells typically acquire 81 no more than one coding plasmid and most cells are negative. Cells were incubated with RBD-82 sfGFP-containing medium and co-stained with fluorescent anti-myc to detect surface ACE2 by 83 flow cytometry. During analysis, the top 67% (magenta gate) were chosen from the ACE2-84 positive population (purple gate) (B). Bound RBD was subsequently measured relative to 85 surface ACE2 expression (C).

FIGREF4.text: D) Expi293F cells were transfected with an ACE2 single site-saturation mutagenesis library and 87 analyzed as in B. During FACS, the top 15% of cells with bound RBD relative to ACE2 88 expression were collected (nCoV-S-High sort, green gate) and the bottom 20% were collected 89 separately (nCoV-S-Low sort, blue gate).

Nonsynonymous mutations 113 are black, nonsense mutations are red. Replicate 1 used a 1/40 dilution and replicate 2 used a 114 1/20 dilution of RBD-sfGFP-containing medium. R 2 values are for nonsynonymous mutations.

FIGREF11.text: C) Average log 2 enrichment ratios tend to be anticorrelated between the nCoV-S-High and 116 nCoV-S-Low sorts. Nonsense mutations (red) and a small number of nonsynonymous 117 mutations (black) are not expressed at the plasma membrane and are depleted from both sort 118 populations (i.e. fall below the diagonal).

FIGREF12.text: D-F) Correlation plots of residue conservation scores from replicate nCoV-S-High (D) and 120 nCoV-S-Low (E) sorts, and from the averaged data from both nCoV-S-High sorts compared to 121 both nCoV-S-Low sorts (F). Conservation scores are calculated from the mean of the log 2 122 enrichment ratios for all amino acid substitutions at each residue position.

FIGREF15.text: B) Average hydrophobicity-weighted enrichment ratios are mapped to the RBD-bound ACE2 147 structure, with residues tolerant of polar substitutions in blue, while residues that prefer 148 hydrophobic amino acids are yellow.

FIGREF16.text: C) A magnified view of part of the ACE2 (colored by conservation score as in A) / RBD (pale 150 green) interface. Accompanying heatmap plots log 2 enrichment ratios from the nCoV-S-High 151 sort for substitutions of ACE2-T27, D30 and K31 from ≤ -3 (depleted) in orange to ≥ +3 152 (enriched) in dark blue.

Unexplored combinations of mutations 192 may have even greater effects. 193 Single amino acid substitutions in ACE2 predicted from the deep mutational 195 scan to increase RBD binding have small effects. 196 (A) Expi293F cells expressing full length ACE2 were stained with RBD-sfGFP-containing 197 medium and analyzed by flow cytometry. Data are compared between wild type ACE2 (black) 198 and a single mutant (L79T, red). Increased RBD binding is most discernable in cells expressing 199 low levels of ACE2 (blue gate). In this experiment, ACE2 has an extracellular N-terminal myc 200 tag upstream of residue S19 that is used to detect surface expression. 201 (B) RBD-sfGFP binding was measured for 30 single amino acid substitutions in ACE2. Data are 202 GFP mean fluorescence in the low expression gate (blue gate in panel A) with background 203 fluorescence subtracted.

FIGREF18.text: C) RBD-sfGFP binding measured for the total ACE2-positive population (green gate in panel A) 205 is shown in the upper graph, while the lower graph plots ACE2 expression measured by 206 detection of the extracellular myc tag. Total RBD-sfGFP binding correlates with total ACE2 207 expression, and differences in binding between the mutants are therefore most apparent only 208 after controlling for expression levels as in panel A.209 210

The competing proteins were 267 added simultaneously to cells expressing full length S, and bound proteins were detected by 268 flow cytometry.

FIGREF37.text: F) Wild type sACE2-8h association (t = 0 to 120 s) and dissociation (t > 120 s) with immobilized 311 RBD-IgG1 measured by BLI. Data are comparable to a second independent preparation of 312 sACE2-8h shown inFigure 8C.

FIGREF38.text: G) BLI kinetics of sACE2.v2.4-8h with immobilized RBD-IgG1. 314 While deep mutagenesis of viral proteins in replicating viruseshas been extensively 315 pursued to understand escape mechanisms from drugs and antibodies, the work here 316 shows how deep mutagenesis can be directly applicable to anti-viral protein design when 317the selection method is decoupled from virus replication and focused on host factors. 318METHODS 319Plasmids. The mature polypeptide (a.a. 19-805) of human ACE2 (GenBank NM_021804.1) 320 was cloned in to the NheI-XhoI sites of pCEP4 (Invitrogen) with a N-terminal HA leader 321 (MKTIIALSYIFCLVFA), myc-tag, and linker (GSPGGA). Soluble ACE2 fused to superfolder 322 GFP (34) was constructed by genetically joining the protease domain (a.a. 1-615) of ACE2 323 to sfGFP (GenBank ASL68970) via a gly/ser-rich linker (GSGGSGSGG), and pasting between 324 the NheI-XhoI sites of pcDNA3.1(+) (Invitrogen). Equivalent sACE2 constructs were cloned 325 with a GSG linker and 8 histidine tag, or a GS linker and the Fc region of IgG1 (a.a. D221-326 K447). A synthetic human codon-optimized gene fragment (Integrated DNA Technologies) 327 for the RBD (a.a. 333-529) of SARS-CoV-2 S (GenBank YP_009724390.1) was N-terminally 328 fused to a HA leader and C-terminally fused to either superfolder GFP, the Fc region of IgG1 329 or a 8 histidine tag. Assembled DNA fragments were ligated in to the NheI-XhoI sites of 330 pcDNA3.1(+). Human codon-optimized full length S was subcloned from pUC57-2019-331 nCoV-S(Human) (Molecular Cloud), both untagged (a.a. 1-1273) and with a N-terminal HA 332 leader (MKTIIALSYIFCLVFA), myc-tag and linker (GSPGGA) upstream of the mature 333 polypeptide (a.a. 16-1273). 334 Tissue Culture. Expi293F cells (ThermoFisher) were cultured in Expi293 Expression 335 Medium (ThermoFisher) at 125 rpm, 8 % CO2, 37 °C. For production of RBD-sfGFP, RBD-336IgG1, sACE2-8h and sACE2-IgG1, cells were prepared to 2 × 10 6 / ml. Per ml of culture, 500 337 ng of plasmid and 3 µg of polyethylenimine (MW 25,000; Polysciences) were mixed in 100 338µl of OptiMEM (Gibco), incubated for 20 minutes at room temperature, and added to cells. 339

FIGREF39.text: 378 cytometry 24 h post-transfection. To analyze binding of RBD-sfGFP to full length myc-379 ACE2, cells were washed with ice-cold PBS-BSA, and incubated for 30 minutes on ice with a 380 1/30 dilution of medium containing RBD-sfGFP and a 1/240 dilution of anti-myc Alexa 647 381 (clone 9B11, Cell Signaling Technology). Cells were washed twice with PBS-BSA and 382 analyzed on a BD LSR II. To analyze binding of sACE2-sfGFP to full length myc-S, cells were 383 washed with PBS-BSA, and incubated for 30 minutes on ice with a serial dilution of medium 384 containing sACE2-sfGFP and a 1/240 dilution of anti-myc Alexa 647 (clone 9B11, Cell 385 Signaling Technology). Cells were washed twice with PBS-BSA and analyzed on a BD 386 Accuri C6, with the entire Alexa 647-positive population gated for analysis. To measure 387 binding of sACE2-IgG1 or sACE2-8h, myc-S or S transfected cells were washed with PBS-388 BSA and incubated for 30 minutes with the indicated concentrations of purified sACE2 in 389 PBS-BSA. Cells were washed twice, incubated with secondary antibody (1/100 dilution of 390 chicken anti-HIS-FITC polyclonal from Immunology Consultants Laboratory; or 1/250 anti-391

TABREF0.text: The ACE2 library was transiently expressed in human Expi293F cells under conditions that 59

TABREF1.text: Mining the data identifies many ACE2 mutations that are enriched for RBD binding. For 154 instance, there are 122 mutations to 35 positions in the library that have log2 enrichment 155 ratios >1.5 in the nCoV-S-High sort. By comparing the mutational landscape with human 156 genetic diversity, it has been proposed that ACE2 polymorphisms are relevant to COVID-19 157 pathogenesis and transmission (36, 37), although this will require further validation. At 158 least a dozen ACE2 mutations at the structurally characterized interface enhance RBD 159

TABREF3.text: ThermoFisher) according to the manufacturer's directions, with 345 Transfection Enhancers added 22-1 / 2 h post-transfection, and medium supernatant 346 harvested after 60 h. 347 Deep mutagenesis. 117 residues within the protease domain of ACE2 were diversified by 348 overlap extension PCR (41) using primers with degenerate NNK codons. The plasmid 349 library was transfected in to Expi293F cells using Expifectamine under conditions 350 previously shown to typically give no more than a single coding variant per cell (32, 33); 1 351 ng coding plasmid was diluted with 1,500 ng pCEP4-ΔCMV carrier plasmid per ml of cell 352 culture at 2 × 10 6 / ml, and the medium was replaced 2 h post-transfection. The cells were 353 collected after 24 h, washed with ice-cold PBS supplemented with 0.2 % bovine serum 354 albumin (PBS-BSA), and incubated for 30 minutes on ice with a 1/20 (replicate 1) or 1/40 355 (replicate 2) dilution of medium containing RBD-sfGFP into PBS-BSA. Cells were co-stained 356 with anti-myc Alexa 647 (clone 9B11, 1/250 dilution; Cell Signaling Technology). Cells 357 were washed twice with PBS-BSA, and sorted on a BD FACS Aria II at the Roy J. Carver 358 Biotechnology Center. The main cell population was gated by forward/side scattering to 359 remove debris and doublets, and DAPI was added to the sample to exclude dead cells. Of 360
